greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest Product_{i:lambda} prime(i) for any perfect partition lambda of n.
comment: A perfect partition of n contains a unique partition for any k in {0,...,n}.  See also A002033.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..3000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Perfect Partition
example: For n=7 there are 4 perfect partitions: [4,1,1,1], [4,2,1], [2,2,2,1] and [1,1,1,1,1,1,1], their encodings as Product_{i:lambda} prime(i) give 56, 42, 54, 128, respectively.  The smallest value is a(7) = 42.
mathematica: b[n_, l_] := If[n==1, 2^(l[[1]]-1)*Product[Prime[Product[l[[j]], {j, 1, i-1}]]^(l[[i]]-1), {i, 2, Length[l]}], Min[Table[b[n/d, Append[l, d]], {d, Divisors[n] ~Complement~ {1}}]]];
Table[a[n], {n, 0, 42}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 23 2017, translated from Maple *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Jul 09 2015
